Like other Italian hot sauces, it’s fueled with combustible Calabrian chiles. Here’s a complete rundown of where to find all the major awards hopefuls.

title: The Architects Who, After a Devastating Earthquake, Rebuilt a Town
description: Jojutla, Mexico, now home to an array of inventively reimagined public spaces, has become a paradigm for rural revitalization.
content: AT 1:14 P.M. ON SEPT. 19, 2017, the ground began to shake under the town of Jojutla, in the Mexican state of Morelos, 50 miles south of Mexico City. The iron bells in the 18th-century Chapel of San Miguel Arcángel thundered as the clock tower cracked and slid from its perch, crashing through the portico of the parish’s administrative offices. Seconds later, the apse collapsed into a pile of rubble. At the far end of the nearly 40,000-square-foot complex, the gymnasium-like Santuario del Señor de Tula, a church built in 2001 to accommodate 1,000 parishioners, lurched a few centimeters to the west. The cavernous building pulled at the 19th-century arcade to which its northern facade had been anchored, shattering the delicate brick keystones.

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy imposes lockdown measures as cases spike across Europe.
description: A year after the virus began spreading in Europe, things feel unnervingly the same.
content: A year after Italy became the first European country to impose a national lockdown to contain the spread of the coronavirus, the nation has fallen eerily quiet once again, with new restrictions imposed on Monday in an effort to stop a third wave of infections that is threatening to wash over Europe and overwhelm its halting mass inoculation program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Yes, America, There Is (Some) Hope for the Environment
description: Wildlife bridges, plastic-eating bacteria and drones that plant trees remind us that we are as good at repairing as we are at destroying.
content: NASHVILLE — I’ve been keeping a collection of links to good news about the environment as a hedge against despair when so much of the news from nature is devastating. Rolling pandemics. The near annihilation of birds and insects. Even the end of sharks. In short, a “ghastly future of mass extinction, declining health and climate-disruption upheavals,” according to a recent report in Frontiers in Conservation Science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Vaccinated Americans have been getting their second doses on time, the C.D.C. says.
description: Federal health officials urged local vaccinators to take steps to ensure that everyone comes back, including scheduling a return appointment when giving the first shot, sending reminders, and rescheduling missed or canceled appointments.
content: Nearly nine in 10 Americans who received the first dose of a two-dose Covid-19 vaccine went on to complete the regimen, and most people who received two doses got them within the recommended time frames, federal health officials reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: This Passover Recipe Tells the Story of a Family Tree
description: A wide-reaching family’s interpretations of a Moroccan Jewish recipe reflects their history.
content: The mention of a Moroccan fish dish stirs Dafna Tapiero’s memory — of a jar of saffron water perched on her grandmother’s counter in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: 2021 Oscars Nominations: Snubs and Surprises for Daniel Kaluuya, Lakeith Stanfield and Jodie Foster
description: The two men are up for supporting actor in “Judas and the Black Messiah,” a best picture candidate. So who was the star? And the Globes’ best supporting actress was shut out.
content: Plenty of history was made when the Academy Award nominations were announced Monday morning, but it just wouldn’t be the Oscars without a few swerves and head-scratching omissions. Below, the Projectionist surveys the biggest surprises and most high-profile snubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Andra Day Earns a Best Actress Nomination for ‘The United States vs. Billie Holiday’
description: “It shouldn’t be an uncomfortable idea that it could be all Black women being represented in this space,” said the star, who’s also working on a new album.
content: Not even an Oscar nomination could curtail Andra Day’s productivity. The Junk Jedis had arrived to clean out her garage, and, well, Monday was as good as any.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Justin Thomas Surges to Win the Players Championship
description: Thomas, who entered the final round Sunday three strokes behind the leader, won his 14th career title on the PGA Tour.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — It was evident early that the final round of the Players Championship might not unfold as expected when Bryson DeChambeau took one of his trademark mighty swipes and barely made contact with the top of his golf ball, which nose-dived and skittered into a pond roughly 100 yards away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Met Opera’s Musicians, Unpaid Since April, Are Struggling
description: About 40 percent of the players have left the New York area, and a tenth have retired. Now the Met is seeking long-term pay cuts, and offering them partial pay if they come to the bargaining table.
content: As the months without a paycheck wore on, Joel Noyes, a 41-year-old cellist with the Metropolitan Opera, realized that in order to keep making his mortgage payments he would have to sell one of his most valuable possessions: his 19th-century Russian bow. He reluctantly switched back to the inferior one he had used as a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Grisly Killing in Syria Spawns Legal Case Against Russian Mercenaries
description: Rights groups filed the litigation, linked to footage of a captive being dismembered, in an effort to close loopholes that enable nonstate militias to evade the rules of war.
content: MOSCOW — Three human rights groups announced on Monday a legal action that they say is the first to target soldiers from the Russian mercenary organization Wagner for crimes committed in Syria, highlighting growing efforts to hold accountable contract soldiers in war zones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Rosalind Cartwright, Psychologist and ‘Queen of Dreams,’ Dies at 98
description: An early researcher of sleep disorders and the role of dreams in emotional health, she studied her subjects’ nights to help them turn their days around.
content: In 1999, Rosalind D. Cartwright, a sleep expert, testified for the defense in the murder trial of a man who had arisen from his bed early one night, gathered up tools to fix his pool’s filter pump, stabbed his beloved wife to death, rolled her into the pool and gone back to bed. When he was awakened by the police, he said he had no memory of his actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Beyoncé not only came to the Grammys, she won four and made history.
description: After winning for best rap song with Megan Thee Stallion and for best R&B performance, Beyoncé has won more Grammys than any other female artist.
content: Beyoncé not only showed up at the Grammys (surprise!) — she won four, broke a record, and then got onstage to offer gracious remarks on a night when she was nominated nine times but did not perform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Promising Young Woman’ Director Emerald Fennell on Her Historic Oscar Nomination
description: For the first time, two women are up for best director, but a daylight-saving time mix-up almost kept the filmmaker from the announcement.
content: “Promising Young Woman” has been a major player this awards season, and writer-director Emerald Fennell had every reason to expect that Monday’s Oscar nominations would bring even more good news for her first feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Landing a One-Bedroom, With a Little Help From Her Friends
description: The power of community helped a longtime Park Slope, Brooklyn, resident find a new home.
content: When Pam McAllister discovered that she had to leave her Park Slope, Brooklyn, apartment of 37 years in 2015, she did the only thing that she could think of: She emailed 100 or so friends, asking for help.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Interactive video shopping, popularized by TV networks like QVC, has moved online.
description: Matt Granite, who goes by The Deal Guy, streams daily on Amazon Live, covering everything from kitchen gadgets to snowblowers. Under each video is a carousel display of the products he’s discussing. When a viewer clicks that item and buys it, Mr. Granite gets a cut, with commissions varying from 10 percent for luxury and beauty products to 1 percent for Amazon Fresh items. Mr. Granite’s YouTube channel still brings in more revenue through ad rolls and sponsorships, but he said the revenue and audience numbers for his Amazon Live videos have grown over the past year.

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A.I. Is Not What You Think
description: Artificial intelligence technology is promising, but it’s not a magic potion. Oh well.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Zack Snyder’s Justice League’ Review: Supersized, Super Hopeless
description: Snyder’s marathon cut of his film for HBO Max doesn’t add much to be happy about.
content: No one knows hope like a fan: hope that your favorite writer won’t disappoint with the next chapter, hope that a character will triumph, hope that the heroes will save the day. Hope is baked into the pages of comic-book stories, which often subscribe to a belief that good and evil exist in a clear-cut binary, and that a light will always shine through, even in the darkest days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Sports Are Returning to Normal. So Is Their Role in Political Fights.
description: American society is redrawing cultural norms and protections for citizens’ rights. It shouldn’t be a shock that sports is the most visible battleground.
content: The end of the terrible coronavirus pandemic seems, at long last, within reach. President Donald J. Trump is gone and America has just endured a withering year of death and protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Afraid of Needles? Don’t Let It Keep You From a Covid-19 Vaccine.
description: There are ways to overcome a fear of needles. Here’s how.
content: Most people aren’t particularly fond of needles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Movies released in 2021 seem to have momentum.
description: Time is not a reliable construct in this year’s awards race. With two months added to the nomination process, conventional thinking has been thrown out the window.
content: Time is not a reliable construct in this year’s awards race. With two months added to the nomination process, conventional thinking has been thrown out the window.

author: By Mitt Romney
title: The Right Way to Boycott the Beijing Olympics
description: The United States can repudiate Chinese policy without unfairly punishing our athletes.
content: As the Beijing Olympic Games approach, it is increasingly clear that China, under the control of the Chinese Communist Party does not deserve an Olympic showcase. Because it is too late to move the Winter Games scheduled for Beijing next February, some have proposed, understandably, that the United States boycott the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Mixer Adds Zip to Summer Coolers
description: A sparkling water flavored with lime and yuzu is a nice change of pace from tonic in a mixed drink.
content: You might change your gin and tonic order this summer. Fever-Tree, a British company that specializes in high-quality carbonated mixers, has doubled down on tart citrus in its new sparkling lime and yuzu flavor. It performs beautifully with a shot of gin, vodka, white rum or even tequila plata. The refreshment comes from its restrained sweetness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden administration officials have tried to restart talks with North Korea.
description: The administration has tried to restart discussions with North Korea over the fate of its nuclear program, but its overtures have not been returned, the White House press secretary confirmed.
content: The Biden administration has tried to restart discussions with North Korea over the fate of its nuclear program, but its overtures have not been returned, the White House press secretary confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Fortini
title: Simon Doonan Has Been Keeping Busy
description: While you were tweeting away your quarantine, the former creative director of Barneys published two books. One about self-help. And one about Keith Haring (and self-help).
content: A little more than a year ago, I visited the Barneys Manhattan flagship store while it was in the final throes of its liquidation sale. It looked like the rapture had just happened. The pale beige carpet and matching velvet sofas were strewn with partnerless shoes and discarded pieces of trash, as though feral shoppers had tossed them on the floor when they lost interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden heralds the deployment of 100 million shots and 100 million stimulus checks.
description: “Shots in arms and money in pockets. That’s important,” Mr. Biden said in a brief address from the White House.
content: President Biden said Monday that his administration was on pace to achieve two key goals by March 25: the distribution of 100 million shots of Covid-19 vaccines since his inauguration and 100 million checks and electronic deposits of stimulus payments under his economic relief bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Day the Bay Area Shut Down
description: Monday: A year into the pandemic, California is reopening. Here’s a look back at the day it started shutting down.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Life After the Vaccine in Israel
description: Half the country has been inoculated, ushering in a kind of normalcy that is largely defined by the people it excludes.
content: Just a few months ago, Israel was in dire shape when it came to the coronavirus. It had among the highest daily infection and death rates in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volkswagen Aims to Use Its Size to Head Off Tesla
description: The German carmaker outlined ambitious goals to build battery factories as it ties its fate to electric cars.
content: Volkswagen is going all in on electric cars, with plans to build battery factories in Europe, install a network of charging stations and slash the cost of emission-free travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Has Lost Popularity, but Half of N.Y. Voters Say He Shouldn’t Resign
description: A Siena College poll showed that more than a third of voters believed Gov. Andrew Cuomo committed sexual harassment, and a slight majority wanted “someone else” to run for governor next year.
content: More New Yorkers believe that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has committed sexual harassment than not, but half of those surveyed say that he should not immediately resign, according to a Siena College poll released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘In Nepal and Across the World, Child Marriage Is Rising’
description: In this lesson, students will examine the causes and consequences of child marriage. Then they will consider how best to inform and educate others.
content: Featured Article: “In Nepal and Across the World, Child Marriage Is Rising” by Bhadra Sharma and Jeffrey Gettleman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Taylor Swift takes album of the year, becoming the first woman to win three times.
description: The singer-songwriter’s pandemic album “Folklore” joins “Fearless” and “1989” as winners of the Grammys’ biggest prize for an LP.
content: Taylor Swift’s “Folklore” won album of the year on Sunday, making the singer and songwriter the first woman to win the prize three times, following her victories for “Fearless” in 2010 and “1989” in 2016. Swift tied Frank Sinatra, Stevie Wonder and Paul Simon as the only artists with three career best album trophies. (The mastering engineer Tom Coyne has won four, including one for “1989.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: It’s OK to Grieve for the Small Losses of a Lost Year
description: There is a name for grief that isn’t routinely acknowledged: disenfranchised grief.
content: When I’ve asked people what they lost in the past year of pandemic life, the answer often starts the same way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Can Biden Stay on the Sidelines of the Andrew Cuomo Saga?
description: The New York governor has been abandoned by top Democrats in his state, but the president is asking for investigations to proceed before passing judgment.
content: So far, President Biden has made only a passing comment on the crises that have engulfed Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and he seems to be hoping to avoid getting pulled in any further.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy’ and ‘Genius: Aretha’
description: Revisit the 2011 adaptation of John le Carré’s “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.” Or see Cynthia Erivo play Aretha Franklin in National Geographic’s “Genius: Aretha.”
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Old World Wines Are Savored in ‘Noble Rot’
description: Dan Keeling and Mark Andrew’s new book covers old territory in a fresh way.
content: In their hefty tome “The Noble Rot Book: Wine From Another Galaxy,” Dan Keeling and Mark Andrew walk a fine line between easygoing but intelligent wine basics for beginners and deep dives into their favorite wineries in Europe. The Noble Rot part — a term that refers to the fungus that can attack grapes and make their juices sweeter — is the name of their cheeky magazine and their London restaurants. Their profiles of the dozens of wineries, winemakers and the bottles that inhabit their wine universe, strictly Old World in France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Germany, Greece and England, are thoughtful, personal and richly informative. It’s a good Burgundy of a wine book, one that deserves savoring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Grammys Discover Youth
description: A pandemic awards show that seemed poised to disappoint ended up pivoting instead, shifting its focus to women, hip-hop and most crucially, the next generation.
content: The annual postgame bemoaning of the Grammys rarely fails to disappoint. Between its consistently fraught relationship with Black artists, its weighing down of the young with the old, and its stoic resistance to the ways in which pop music is evolving, the ceremony has become as powerful for its symbolic out-of-touchness as for its commemorations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Virus Variants Likely Evolved Inside People With Weak Immune Systems
description: Growing evidence suggests that people with cancer and other conditions that challenge their immune systems may be incubators of mutant viruses.
content: The version of the coronavirus that surfaced in Britain late last year was shocking for many reasons. It came just as vaccines had offered a glimpse of the end of the pandemic, threatening to dash those hopes. It was far more contagious than earlier variants, leading to a swift increase in hospitalizations. And perhaps most surprising to scientists: It had amassed a large constellation of mutations seemingly overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: A Debut Novel With Prose as Lively as Its Heroine’s Mind
description: Christine Smallwood’s “The Life of the Mind” features an adjunct English professor coping with the end of her pregnancy, and everything else.
content: Christine Smallwood’s debut novel, “The Life of the Mind,” advertises its intellectual side in the title. Its first sentence makes clear that it will also cover the scatological. Dorothy, an adjunct professor of English, is sitting in a public toilet, worried about her sixth day of bleeding after a miscarriage and ignoring a call from her therapist.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Millions of workers without job are going uncounted in the unemployment rate.
description: In the year since the pandemic upended the economy, more than four million people have quit the labor force. They are not counted in the most commonly cited unemployment rate, which stood at 6.2 percent in February, making the group something of a hidden casualty of the pandemic.

title: Myanmar Authorities Declare Martial Law in Parts of Country’s Largest City
description: The move in Yangon by the ruling junta came after dozens of people protesting a military coup last month were killed by security forces.
content: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s ruling junta has declared martial law in six townships in Yangon, the country’s largest city, after security forces killed dozens of protesters over the weekend in an increasingly lethal crackdown on resistance to a military coup last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Kathy Hochul, Cuomo’s Loyal Lieutenant, Is Tested as Crisis Engulfs Him
description: Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul would become New York’s first female governor if Gov. Andrew Cuomo resigns or is removed from office amid sexual harassment allegations.
content: BUFFALO — On the day that embattled Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo lost the support of the New York State Senate leader, marking the start of the most perilous week of his career yet, the woman who could succeed him in office was celebrating National Cereal Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Will Democrats Nix (or Weaken) the Filibuster?
description: Many of their priorities have little chance of becoming law — unless they shake up Senate procedure.
content: Major investments in infrastructure and green jobs. Expansions to voting rights and reforms to the democratic process. Strong new protections for labor unions. Universal background checks on gun sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Most Valuable Democrat
description: Progressives like to complain about Joe Manchin. But nothing would help Democrats as much as more Joe Manchins.
content: The structure of the Senate has not always favored Republicans. But in recent decades, heavily white and rural communities have moved to the political right. Because these communities dominate many small states, and because small states enjoy a lot of power in the Senate, it now has a large pro-Republican bias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Billie Eilish wins record of the year but says Megan Thee Stallion deserved it.
description: While accepting the award for the second year in a row, the 19-year-old singer asked the audience to applaud instead for the other nominee.
content: Billie Eilish won record of the year for the second year in a row, but when she got onstage to accept the award, she said that Megan Thee Stallion was the one who deserved it, asking the audience to cheer for the rapper instead of her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Monarchy, Meet Anarchy
description: President Biden is not the only one who wants to celebrate Independence Day.
content: Bret Stephens: Well, Gail, President Biden just signed the biggest stimulus bill in history, Andrew Cuomo is facing mounting pressures to resign and the only thing people seem really interested in is … Harry and Meghan versus the House of Windsor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael Wines
title: For Voting Rights Advocates, a ‘Once in a Generation Moment’ Looms
description: Opposition to restrictive Republican voting laws — and support for a sweeping Democratic bill — fuels a movement like none in decades. But can it succeed?
content: WASHINGTON — State and national voting-rights advocates are waging the most consequential political struggle over access to the ballot since the civil rights era, a fight increasingly focused on a far-reaching federal overhaul of election rules in a last-ditch bid to offset a wave of voting restrictions sweeping Republican-controlled state legislatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Eric Schmitt
title: American Soldiers Help Mozambique Battle an Expanding ISIS Affiliate
description: With a small military training program, the United States military has joined efforts to fight a brutal insurgency that has devastated northern Mozambique.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — American Special Forces soldiers began training Mozambican troops this week as part of an effort to repel a spreading insurgency in northeastern Mozambique that American officials say is linked to the Islamic State. The insurgency, near some of the world’s biggest gas reserves, has killed at least 2,000 civilians and displaced another 670,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Germany, France and Italy suspend the AstraZeneca shot.
content: Germany, France and Italy became the latest countries to suspend the Covid-19 vaccine from Oxford-AstraZeneca, citing reports of unusual blood clotting problems among a few people who recently received the shots in Norway. Denmark, Iceland, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Indonesia and the Netherlands have also suspended AstraZeneca vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: America Could Use a Liberal Party
description: The new division in politics isn’t between liberals and conservatives. It’s between liberals and illiberals.
content: Last month, Gallup released the results of a survey showing that public support for a third party was at an all-time high: 62 percent, up from 40 percent when Gallup first started polling the issue in 2003. Only 33 percent of Americans feel the current parties “do an adequate job of representing the American people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Ronald DeFeo, Whose Murder Spree Inspired ‘The Amityville Horror,’ Dies at 69
description: Mr. DeFeo confessed to killing his parents and four siblings in 1974 at their home in Amityville, N.Y. The house became the subject of books and movies.
content: Ronald DeFeo, who was convicted of killing his parents and four siblings at the family’s home in Amityville, N.Y., in 1974 — a spree that spawned a series of books and movies, including the 1979 film “The Amityville Horror” — died on Friday at a hospital in Albany. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: U.K. Policing Bill Examined After Clashes at Sarah Everard Vigil
description: The police’s actions at an event in memory of a woman who was kidnapped and killed in London have put the proposed legislation under a spotlight.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson was meeting with law enforcement officials on Monday after the London police drew widespread criticism for their handling of a vigil on Saturday to mark the killing of a 33-year-old woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Lindsay Zoladz and Caryn Ganz
title: The Best and Worst of the 2021 Grammy Awards
description: Megan Thee Stallion owned the stage, struggling indie venues got a much needed spotlight and the event proved a pandemic awards show doesn’t have to look like a video conference.
content: The 63rd annual Grammy Awards promised to be different: There was a new executive producer at the helm for the first time in decades; a new host; and a new challenge — assembling a pandemic awards show that didn’t feel like a video conference. With a small audience of nominees outside in Los Angeles, the show highlighted the contributions of women and the impact of Black Lives Matter protests, offered screen time to workers at independent venues crushed by the pandemic and extended tributes to musicians we lost during this challenging year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: New E.P.A. Head Says Agency Has Climate Regulations Underway
description: Michael Regan says the E.P.A. is already working on new rules to control planet-warming emissions from cars and power plants.
content: WASHINGTON — Michael S. Regan, the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, confirmed on Monday that the agency is preparing new regulations on the electricity sector in an effort to meet President Biden’s aggressive climate change goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Megan Thee Stallion wins best new artist, the first televised award of the night.
description: Accepting her second Grammy so far, the teary-eyed Houston rapper said, “It’s been a hell of a year, but we made it.”
content: The Houston rapper Megan Thee Stallion won the Grammy for best new artist on Sunday, taking home the first trophy presented on the official telecast. She also won an award during the preshow — best rap performance for “Savage,” a song that is nominated twice more tonight (for best rap song and record of the year).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: How the U.S. Got It (Mostly) Right in the Economy’s Rescue
description: Though the recession has been painful, policymakers cushioned the pandemic’s blow and opened the way to recovery.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic ripped a hole in the economy a year ago, many feared that the United States would repeat the experience of the last recession, when a timid and short-lived government response, in the view of many experts, led to years of high unemployment and anemic wage growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Los Angeles Museums Can Reopen, at 25 Percent Capacity
description: Struggling from financial losses, museums in Los Angeles are eager to welcome visitors again after being shut for a year, but it may take a few weeks to reopen.
content: LOS ANGELES — Having been closed for a year, museums were finally granted the right to reopen indoors at 25 percent capacity on Monday when the state moved Los Angeles County into its less restrictive red tier of Covid-19 regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Oscar Nominations 2021: Two Black Women Are Up for Best Actress
description: Andra Day and Viola Davis are the category’s first pair of Black nominees since 1973, when Diana Ross was nominated for “Lady Sings the Blues” and Cicely Tyson was up for “Sounder.”
content: Andra Day was just the second Black woman to win best actress in a drama at the Golden Globes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Pandemic as a Wake-Up Call for Personal Health
description: Too many Americans fail to take measures to combat obesity, the second leading risk factor for death from Covid-19.
content: The pandemic has shed a blinding light on too many Americans’ failure to follow the well-established scientific principles of personal health and well-being. There are several reasons this country, one of the world’s richest and most highly developed, has suffered much higher rates of Covid-19 infections and deaths than many poorer and less well-equipped populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Capitol Police Will Begin Scaling Back Fencing Put Up After Riot
description: An inner perimeter will be moved closer to the building and an outer perimeter will be removed altogether as Congress tries to return to normal after the Jan. 6 attack.
content: The Capitol Police in the coming days will begin scaling back and in some cases removing fencing erected around the Capitol after the Jan. 6 riot, a Democratic aide familiar with the plans confirmed on Sunday, a visible milestone as Congress tries to return to normal.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Kosterina extra-virgin olive oil, made in the Peloponnese in southern Greece, has been sold in the United States for about a year. Now the company has introduced an olive oil cake: a moist, delicate layer made with yogurt, a hint of orange and the company’s golden, slightly assertive 100 percent koroneiki olive oil. The cake is lovely just dusted with the powdered sugar that comes alongside, but it also justifies some orange sorbet or whipped cream and lightly poached Clementine segments. (You could also add seasonal berries.) Shipping to the Northeast is $10; elsewhere, $15. It holds up to a week in the refrigerator. Order by March 30 to have it in time for Easter.
